ENLU, ENLU General
27.1 ENLU General
� General Information
The aggregate ENLU - ENgine LUbrication bundles at the moment only the functionality belonging to the
so-called service interval extension ( abbreviation in German : WIV ).
The service interval extension functionality extracts from oil level and oil wear/soot equivalents the distance
which can be driven with the car until the next oil service in the garage. A detailed description of the function-
ality will follow later.
2 different strategies are supported by the AGGR ENLU: WIV3 and WIV4.
For WIV3 in principle only the following 2 specs are necessary:
- 400S for determination of oil temperature TOIL used within other AGGRs
- 906R for determination of oil level and oil wear/soot equivalents sent via bus to other controller
- A0GZ for oil sensor diagnostics
Most of the calculations are done directly in the ICL ( Kombi-instrument ); the ECU makes only the oil level/
temperature determination and the a short-term ?ltering of the oil level and a oil wear/soot equivalent calcula-
tion.
For WIV4 the following specs are relevant:
- 201H for oil level/temperature acquisition of oil sensor signal via ECU-pin or via CAN
- 406P for oil level/temperature determination; oil level measurement while engine stopped or
engine running; calculation of warning ?ags
- 406O for calculation of CAN-output
- 400S for determination of oil temperature TOIL used within other AGGRs
- 906R for oil wear/soot equivalents sent via bus to other controller
- 908S for calculations for the service interval display
- A0GZ for oil sensor diagnostics
Some of the calculations are transferred from ICL to ECU. The ECU determines now the type of the oil level
measurement ( static and/or dynamic ) and sends the warnings depending on the oil level measurements.
� Architecture Overview
27.1.1 201H - Acquisition of the thermal oil sensor
If the sensor is directly connected with the ECU, the basic software reads at every rising edge the low time
T_SIG_L_LOIL since the last falling edge and the high time T_SIG_H_LOIL between the last rising and falling
edge.
If the sensor is not directly connected to the ECU via pin, the necessary signals are provided via CAN. There
is information about the TOG message, the oil level times and the oil temperature time.
The oil level information and the oil temperature information are coded in the high/low times which are re-
ceived via ECU-pin.
The following signals are calculated with the received high/low times:
- T_COOL_LOIL, which is the cool-off time of the thermal oil level sensor and
which corresponds with the measured oil level,
- T_REF_SIG_LEN_LOIL, which is the reference time of the sensor
- T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL, which is the oil temperature signal

ENLU, ENLU General
Figure 27.1.1:
27.1.2 406P- Acquisition of oil level and temperature
In this function the following calculations are performed:
- oil temperature determination
- check of static measurement conditions
- performing of static measurement and setting of ?ags indicating a valid static measurement
- check of dynamic measurement conditions
- performing of dynamic measurement and setting of ?ags indicating a valid dynamic measurement
- performing of short-term and long-term ?ltering of measured dynamic oil level
- calculation of warnings depending on measured oil level ( over?ll-, under?ll- and min-warning )
- weighting of static/dynamic measurement and oil level in %
The oil level and the warnings are sent to ICL/Kombi for displaying information to driver and for service interval
calculation.
27.1.3 406O - Oil temperature model (Appl. Inc.)
Calculation of variables for CAN-output.
27.1.4 400S - Oil Temperature (PULS-Sensor/Model usage)
In this module the system oil temperature TOIL is calculated. There are two oil temperatures present in the
system. One the TOIL_MDL is output of a temperature model. The other oil temperature TOIL_SRV_INTL is
output of the maintenance/service interval extension (WIV) and is extracted from sensor information. It is
calculated out of the signal from the PULS-Sensor, which delivers the oil temperature and the oil level.
Via calibration label CLF_TOIL_SRV_INTL_DI_CONF the source for system oil temperature TOIL can be sel-
sected. Normally the oil temperature model TOIL_MDL is selected. This is done to avoid a complex OBD-
diagnostic for the oil sensor.
27.1.5 906R - Calculation of lubrication maintenance interval
It has to be distinguished between WIV3- and WIV4-functionality; the operating system is divided into 4 sub-
systems:
- SRV_INTL_EQ_CALC which is calculated always ( WIV3/4 )and
- SRV_INTL_CALC, SRV_INTL_CONV and SRV_INTL_OIL_CALC which are calculated only for
WIV-version 3 (LC_OIL_SENS_SYS_VERS = 1)

ENLU, ENLU General
- for WIV3 only:
- oil level is extracted from sensor information received via CAN
- oil level is ?ltered in a median ?lter over 2,4 sec
- every 2,4 sec a new ?ltered oil level is calculated and sent via CAN to ICL
- for WIV3/4:
- calculation of wear equivalent and soot equivalent ( Diesel only ) for transfer via CAN to ICL
- depending on NC_ENG_CONF, Otto or Diesel motor will be set in MSG
- every 2.4s a waste and soot (only for diesel) equivalent will be computed
- every 2s the Flexia Motor will send a message to the station wagon (Kombi), regarding information
about the equivalents, thereby, soot and waste equivalents will be sent alternately
27.1.6 906S - Calculation of lubrication maintenance interval (Appl. Inc.)
The WIV- functionality needs the information about the fuel consumption related to the last 100 ms. This
value is calculated depending on the accumulated fuel consumption (FCO_SUM_CAN). If a over?ow of the
FCO_SUM_CAN is reconized, the calculation is shifted to avoid wrong results.
27.1.7 908S - Oil Control - Calculations for the service interval display
The ?nal outputs to the ICL/Kombi are calculated.
Depending on some tests a plausibility check is performed; depending on this check the warning ?ags and
some other ?ags are transmitted to the ICL/Kombi for illustration to driver.
27.1.8 A0GZ - Oil - plausibility diagnosis
The diagnostic of the oil level sensor consists of 2 parts:
- electrical diagnosis of thermal oil level sensor
- plausibility diagnosis
Electrical diagnosis:
The time T_EDGE_FALL_LOIL gives the time since the last falling edge was detected by the basic software.
If no falling edge was detected for the calibratable threshold C_T_EDGE_FALL_LOIL_MAX_DIAG_EL, the failure
symptom will be set. This electrical diagnosis can always be suppressed by setting LC_OIL_SENS_EL_DIAG_ENA
= 0 and at the case, that the oil sensor signals are provided via CAN, then the parameter LC_LOIL_SENS_SYS_
CONF is set to zero, which leads into a suppression of this diagnosis which results then always with no failure
symptom detected.
Plausibility diagnosis:
There are three possibilities to check the plausibility of the thermal oil level sensor. The ?rst possibility is that
the cool off time has to be between a maximum C_T_COOL_LOIL_MAX_PLAUS and a minimum threshold
C_T_COOL_LOIL_MIN_PLAUS. The second is that the oil temperature signal has to be between a maximum
C_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL_MAX_PLAUS and a minimum threshold C_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL_MIN_PLAUS. The third is that
the ratio of temperature and reference time has to be greater than 1.1.

� General Information
This time is used in signal evaluation. It is the maximum time between two detectable edges. If for more than
this time no edges are detected, no signal is available.
Default setting of this time is 1 second.

ENLU, Acquisition of oil sensor
� Con?guration Data
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
NC_FID_LOIL_TOG_1_VLD V 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Permission from CAN for oil level calculation
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
ACTION_INFR_GetOilSens(OUT <PRM_CTR_FALL_EDGE_SIG>, OUT <PRM_T_SIG_L_LOIL>, OUT <PRM_T_SIG_H_LOIL>)
� General Information
The signals for the oil sensor which are calculated here are following:
T_COOL_LOIL, which is the cool-off time of the thermal oil level sensor,
T_REF_SIG_LEN_LOIL, which is the reference time of the sensor
T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL, which is the temperature signal.
If the sensor is directly connected with the ECU, the basic software reads at every rising edge the low time
T_SIG_L_LOIL since the last falling edge and the high time T_SIG_H_LOIL between the last rising and falling
edge.
If the sensor is not directly connected to the ECU via pin, the necessary signals are provided via CAN. These
are information about the TOG message, the oil level times and the oil temperature time.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, NVMRES, NVMINI, NVMSTO
Activation: LV_ACT == 1
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10MS

27.3.5 Acquisition of thermal oil level sensor for service interval overview
Overview over acquisition of thermal oil level sensor for service interval. The subsystems HW_Connected and
CAN_Connected are created to be able to differentiate between the two possible system con?gurations. The
calibration parameter LC_LOIL_SENS_SYS_CONF re?ects, whether the sensor is directly connected to the ECU
hardware via pin (LC_LOIL_SENS_SYS_CONF = 1) or the sensor information are sent via CAN (LC_LOIL_SENS_
SYS_CONF = 0)

Figure 27.3.7:
27.3.5.1.1 Acquisition of thermal oil level sensor for service interval /Condition for calculation
If a new falling edge is detected (CTR_FALL_EDGE_SIG(n) CTR_FALL_EDGE_SIG(n-1)) and no failure exists from
the basic software, which is indicated by physical max. value of T_SIG_H_LOIL or T_SIG_L_LOIL, the subsystem
calc_loil_signal will be calculated to evaluate the signal of the thermal oil level sensor. At the same time, the
timer for the time since last falling edge was detected will also be reset and counts up until the next new falling
edge is detected.

ENLU, Acquisition of oil sensor
27.3.5.1.2 Calculation of the signals for the thermal oil level sensor
This subsystem consists of two blocks. In the block "conditon_loil_signal" it is evaluated if a new reference time
or a new temperature time was detected. With this information in the block "evaluation_loil_signal" the signal
T_COOL_LOIL, T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL and T_REF_SIG_LEN_LOIL are calculated.

the beginning of sending values oil temperature in start phase (then the sensor sends only "fast oil temper-

available).

Figure 27.3.16:
27.3.5.2 Acquisition of CAN connected thermal oil level sensor for service interval overview
The CAN_Connected subsystem is split into four extra subsystems to provide the same refreshed sensor data
out of the CAN message for further modules as the HW_Connected subsystem. Due to the fact, that there is
no information available via CAN for the time since last falling edge and for the reference time, here, default
values in form of calibration parameters are used.

� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
In this module the system oil temperature is calculated. There are two oil temperatures present in the system.
One the TOIL_MDL is output of a temperature model. The other TOIL_SRV_INTL is output of the maintenance/
service interval extension (WIV) model. It is calculated out of the signal from the PULS-Sensor, which delivers
the oil temperature and the oil level. This TOILSRV_INTL should be used for TOIL calculation. In case of an
error of the oil sensor it should be switched to the TOIL_MDL. This also can be done in case of no ignition key
on or a certain time after start or always. This is depending on the CLF_TOIL_SRV_INTL_DI_CONF.
CLF_TOIL_SRV_INTL_DI_CONF description
.bit0 disables TOIL_SRV_INTL usage always
.bit1 disables TOIL_SRV_INTL usage in case of LV_IGK = 0 and LV_WKU_CAN = 1 so
for active wake up
.bit2 disables TOIL_SRV_INTL usage in case of LV_IGK = 1 and for time after start
IP_T_AST_SRV_INTL_DI
.bit3 disables TOIL_SRV_INTL usage in case of LV_PWL = 1 and LV_WKU_CAN = 0 so
in case of PWL and no active wakeup
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, EXITST
Activation: always
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 100MS

27.7.3.1 Calculation of oil temperature variables
Depending on a present oil sensor error always the TOIL_MDL is used. With CLF_TOIL_SRV_INTL_DI_CONF the
usage of the TOIL_SRV_INTL for calculation of TOIL can be masked out. Three cases for disabling are possible.
Disabling always or in case of no ignition key on or for a certain time after start.
Finally a gradient limiter can avoid to big jumps in the output temperature.

Figure 27.7.5:
27.7.3.1.1 Selection between sensor and model
The modeled oil temperature is used after start at cold engine. At warm engine the measured oil temperature
is more precise. Therefore a switching between modeled and measured oil temperature is necessary.
When engine temperature is greater than a upper threshold ( 85 �C ) and difference between modeled and
measured oil temperature is within an allowed range and sensor values are valid, then the sensor value is used
for TOIL. When engine temperature falls again below a lower threshold ( 80 �C ) or sensor values are not valid
anymore, the modeled values are used again for TOIL.
The toggling between sensor and model values can be avoided via calibration thresholds C_TCO_1_SYS_TOIL_
SENS_ACT_MAX and C_TCO_1_SYS_TOIL_MDL_ACT_MIN; C_TCO_1_SYS_TOIL_SENS_ACT_MAX should be greater
than C_TCO_1_SYS_TOIL_MDL_ACT_MIN.

27.9.2.2 TCO-Gradient for Oil Model in High Path
For oil temperature model correction in high path the TCO-gradient of 25 sec is necessary.
To avoid the storage of 25 TCO-values, not a continuous gradient is calculated, but only every 5 seconds.
This reduces the amount of values to be stored to 5; but with the disadvantage, that only every 5 seconds a
new gradient value is calculated.

27.9.2.3.2.1 Calculation of Correction Factor in case of High Engine Speed/Load
For engines with high performance (Audi S3) under high load and hot environment conditions the oil temper-
ature drifts away to high values ( >140�C). This physical oil temp. characteristic can be modeled insuf?ciently
with the current model.
To improve the model behavior a new correction factor is introduced which increases oil temperature model
under such conditions. This new correction factor depends on air mass ?ow, ambient temperature, oil temp.
and TCO-gradient.

27.10.2 General Overview
27.10.2.1 Oil change detection
LV_OIL_CHG_CAN is provided by CAN after it was set e.g. after oil service in a garage. It is activated for
200km.
If oil change is detected and plausible, the thermodynamic and mechanic-model for fuel in oil must be reset.
For this a trigger-signal is generated once at the rising edge of LV_OIL_CHG_CAN.
Oil change is detected as plausible if condition for outgassing is given and Lamda-correction stay above a
calibratable threshold.
The correction calculation can be aborted if at detected oil change either the mass of fuel in oil is below a
threshold or if the ratio of new input/ old input is above at certain threshold.
The factor for correction calculation can be switched dependent on the ratio of new input/ old input. If at a
plausible detection the new input of fuel-mass is above a threshold, the correction can be less than without
new input into oil.

27.10.2.1.4 Oil change evaluation
LV_OIL_CHG_ACT is the trigger for the correction calculation. It?s set after the rising edge of LV_OIL_CHG_CAN
and if the oil change is plausible.
Until plausibility it can be reset if MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL is below a threshold or if the ration of new input / old
input is to high.

27.10.2.2 Calculation of meanvalue of static oil level
If valid values from static oil level measurement are available, the function creates the mean value up to C_
MAX_CTR_LOIL_STAT_VLD samples continuously. After this amount of samples is reached, new mean values
are build only from whole sample package.
With C_CTR_THD_LOIL_STAT_MV_VLD can be decided, after how many samples the ?rst mean value should
be calculated and get valid.
If the mean value calculation should be based on measurement-samples or time synchronous can be cali-
brated with LC_LOIL_MV_MES_TRIG_DEAC.
LV_LOIL_VALUE_AVL indicates a valid oil level measurement. The ?ag is cleared with engine stop.

� General Information
This module describes the signal conversion of the low and high oil pressure switches and the computation
of the different conditions for the oil pressure warnings. It calculates the different conditions for setting and
clearing the warning ?ags, which will be sent via CAN to the dashboard. It also generates a "migration bit" LV_
POIL_DET_CONF_IDX_COD which initiates the state, if the oil pressure feature is carried out into the dashboard
or if it is carried out in the ECU. The state of the migration ?ag is dependent on the calibratable codeword
C_IDX_COD_POIL_DET_CONF.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: Always
Deactivation: Never
Recurrence: 100MS

27.11.2 Operate
The operation mode is only carried out, if the "migration bit" is set. Because of the possibility to change the
calibratable codeword during measurements, it is necessary to calculate this bit on each recurrence of this
module.
Additional the operation mode is only carried out, if via FARM-interface a permission is available. In case of
problems with oil- or engine temperature the operation mode must not be carried out.

27.11.2.1 OPM Calculation
The calculation of the operation model can be separated in the 3 parts.
The ?rst subsystem contains the calculation of the switch information. The two switches can be activated for
the case, that the logic of the hardware pins is inverted compared to the logic, which is used in the application
software. Normally the value of LC_POIL_DET_IVS is equal to zero. Or a CAN-value is used depending on bit 6
and 7 of C_IDX_COD_POIL_DET_CONF.
The setting and clearing of the high and/or low pressure warning ?ags is the main part of the operation system.
The two subsystems CLC_POIL_SET_WARN and CLC_POIL_CLR_WARN describe in detail, what conditions are
needed to set/clear a high or low oil pressure warning, which will be broadcasted via CAN.
The needed thresholds for the conditions are calculated in the subsystem CLC_THD.

The setting and clearing of the high and/or low pressure warning ?ags is the main part of the operation system.

Figure 27.11.5:
27.11.2.1.2 Calculation of the thresholds
This subsystem shows, how the different thresholds will be calculated out of a selected oil temperature and in
one case additional out of the engine speed.
The delay time for release of oil pressure warning is calculated now depending on the acceleration of the car.
Strong accelerations can result in a relocation of the oil in the oilpan; and then the oil pump can suck air instead
of oil which leads to a break-down of the oil pressure for a short time. Such a short-time interrupt in oil supply
is problem for the engine and shall not be recognized. Therefore an additional delay time for oil pressure
warning is necessary in such conditions.

27.11.2.1.3 Conditions for setting the oil pressure switches warning ?ags
The low oil pressure warning condition is dependent on the state of the fourth bit of the codeword. If it is
set, then the precondition for the low oil pressure warning is ful?lled and if the other preconditions like engine
speed above a calculated threshold and a not activated low oil pressure switch for a calculated period of time,
then the "set-low-warning ?ag" will be raised. Otherwise, it will be deleted.
The high oil pressure warning condition is dependent on the state of the ?fth bit of the codeword. If it is set,
then the precondition for the high oil pressure warning is ful?lled and if the other preconditions like engine
speed above a calculated threshold and an inactive oil pump pressure signal and a not activated high oil
pressure switch for a calculated period of time or if the read in via CAN is enabled and a CAN error is present,
then the "set-high-warning ?ag" will be raised only if the set-low-warning ?ag is not set. Otherwise, it will be
deleted.
To set the warnings the start end ?ag is delayed for a calibratable time.
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission gives the information about the CAN errors present.
IGK is necessary for setting of warning high/low.

27.11.2.1.3.1 Delay-Block
Always this block is used, whenever a subsystem DLY_x is called. If the condition of this block changes from
zero to one, then a counter is started. If the counter is decremented to zero and the condition is still true, then
the block-output is set to one. If the condition changes back to zero, then the output of this block is cleared.

27.11.2.1.4 Conditions for clearing the oil pressure switches warning ?ags
The ?ag which indicates the resetting of the low oil pressure warning is called "clear-low-warning ?ag". It is
dependent on an active low oil pressure switch for a ?xed period of time and an active oil pump pressure
signal or engine speed below a calculated threshold.
The ?ag which indicates the resetting of the high oil pressure warning is called "clear-high-warning ?ag". It is
dependent on an active high oil pressure switch for a ?xed period of time and an inactive oil pump pressure
signal and on the state of the third bit of the codeword. It is also set if the ignition key has an on to off event.

27.12.2.1 Normal operation of the oil pressure switches
After reset, the basic values of the oil pressure switches are directly set to the physical meaning of their corre-
sponding state on the pins. This is only done if the general evaluation of the oil pressure switches is enabled
for the EMS within the codeword C_IDX_COD_POIL_DET_CONF bit 1 and if the pin evaluation of the oil pressure
switches is enabled, done by bit 6 for low oil pressure and bit 7 of the codeword for high oil pressure.

ENLU, Calculation of lubrication maintenance interval
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
GENERAL INFORMATION
- depending on NC_ENG_CONF, Otto or Diesel motor will be set in MSG
- every 2.4s a waste and soot (only for diesel) equivalent will be computed
- every 2s the Flexia Motor will send a message to the station wagon (Kombi), regarding information about
the
equivalents, thereby, soot and waste equivalents will be sent alternately
- the operating system is divided into 4 subsystems:
- SRV_INTL_EQ_CALC which is calculated always and
- SRV_INTL_CALC, SRV_INTL_CONV and SRV_INTL_OIL_CALC which are calculated only for
WIV-version 3 (LC_OIL_SENS_SYS_VERS = 1)
- for WIV3 only:
- oil level is extracted from sensor information received via CAN
- oil level is ?ltered in a median ?lter over 2,4 sec
- every 2,4 sec a new ?ltered oil level is calculated and sent via CAN to ICL
- for WIV3/4:
- calculation of wear equivalent and soot equivalent ( Diesel only ) for transfer via CAN to ICL
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON, NVMRES, NVMINI, NVMSTO
Activation: LV_ACT
Deactivation: !LV_ACT
Recurrence: 100MS

ENLU, Calculation of lubrication maintenance interval
27.13.2 OPERATING SYSTEM
The operating system is divided into 4 subsystems: SRV_INTL_EQ_CALC which is calculated always and SRV_
INTL_CALC, SRV_NITL_CONV and SRV_INTL_OIL_CALC which are calculated only at ENLU requirement version
3 (LC_OIL_SENS_SYS_VERS = 1)
LC_OIL_SENS_SYS_VERS = 0: ENLU version 4
LC_OIL_SENS_SYS_VERS = 1: ENLU version 3

Figure 27.13.27:
27.13.2.3.2.1.1.1 Writing of the vector
Because the vector index is zero-based, the value one of the odd-numbered con?guration parameter NC_NR_
PLS_MES is substracted. Then, the highest possible vector index is always even-numbered and has the value
NC_NR_PLS_MES 1. Normally, the con?guration parameter has the value 9. The FlipFlop is used to detect

LEVEL_SUM_COR.

27.13.2.4.3 SERVICE INTERVAL: EQUIVALENTS COMPUTATION FOR DIESEL
This subsystem is only active for Diesel engine, i.e. NC_ENG_CONF is equal 1.
For the diesel equivalents? computation the following measures will be used: the engine speed, N_WIV, the
computed oil temperature, TOIL_WIV_CLC and the injected fuel quality, FCO_DIF. Two equivalents will be com-
puted here: a wear equivalent out of N_WIV and TOIL_WIV_CLC and a soot equivalent out of FCO_DIF and
N_WIV. The two equivalents will be transmitted alternately; an update of the equivalents will take place every 2
seconds.
Every 2.4s new equivalents are available. The toggle bits indicate if the new equivalents were computed.

27.13.2.4.3.2 SOOT AND WEAR EQUIVALENTS EVALUATION
The basis of computing the soot equivalents are the four maps: IP_SOOT_EQU, IP_QOIL_CH, IP_QOIL_BHC and
IP_QOIL_RGN. The decision about which map will be used to compute the soot index is taken according to the
value of the regeneration state, STATE_RGN_PF.
During drive operation, without regeneration, most of the time, the index values are picked out of IP_SOOT_
EQU map. (default: )If regeneration needs of the particle ?lter are identi?ed, the process of regeneration starts
through a warming-up phase of the oxidation catalytic converter. (case 3: [1] map IP_QOIL_CH selected, case 1:
[4] map IP_QOIL_RGN selected)
The ultimate burning of the soot in the particle ?lter will be identi?ed by a transfer through the burn-up map
IP_QOIL_BHC. (case 2: [2])
The entry signal to the maps IP_QOIL_CH, IP_QOIL_BHC and IP_QOIL_RGN is selectable through an application
switch, LC_SWI_INP, between the total fuel mass, MF_TOT and the sum of the injected fuel mass, MF_INJ_SUM.

27.13.2.4.3.3 SOOT AND WEAR EQUIVALENTS EVALUATION EVERY 100 MS FOR SUMMATION
The basis of computing the soot equivalents are the four maps: IP_SOOT_EQU, IP_QOIL_CH, IP_QOIL_BHC and
IP_QOIL_RGN. The decision about which map will be used to compute the soot index is taken according to the
value of the regeneration state, STATE_RGN_PF.
During drive operation, without regeneration, most of the time, the index values are picked out of IP_SOOT_
EQU map. (default: )If regeneration needs of the particle ?lter are identi?ed, the process of regeneration starts
through a warming-up phase of the oxidation catalytic converter. (case 3: [1] map IP_QOIL_CH selected, case 1:
[4] map IP_QOIL_RGN selected)
The ultimate burning of the soot in the particle ?lter will be identi?ed by a transfer through the burn-up map
IP_QOIL_BHC. (case 2: [2])
The entry signal to the maps IP_QOIL_CH, IP_QOIL_BHC and IP_QOIL_RGN is selectable through an application
switch, LC_SWI_INP, between the total fuel mass, MF_TOT and the sum of the injected fuel mass, MF_INJ_SUM.
Soot and wear equivalents are summed up in temporary variables with high resolution every 100ms for output
to other control units.

27.13.2.4.3.4 OVERFLOW DETECTION INCREASE OF OUTPUT VARIABLES
The output variables to other control units has only a resolution of 0.001.
Therefore the output variables to other control units representing the soot/wear equivalents summation are
only update, when temporary variables with very high resolution exceed the value of 0.001.
When this is the case, soot/wear equivalents summation is incremented by 1 and temporary variables are
reduced by 0.001.

Each time the temporary soot equivalent summation exceeds 0.001, the output variable is incremented by 1
resolution step ( i.e. 0.001 in physical range ).
If output variable reaches over?ow range 32,766 during one active driving cycle, then output summation is
reset to 0 and over?ow bit is set for over?ow indication.

27.13.2.4.4 SERVICE INTERVAL: EQUIVALENTS EVALUATION FOR GASOLINE
This subsystem is only active for gasoline engine, i.e. NC_ENG_CONF is equal 0.
For the computation of the actual service interval for station wagon a, so called, wear equivalent, WEAR_FCO_
EQU will be computed from MSG and transferred through the Motor Flexia message.
Excessive drive operation in too low (short driving rout) or too high (full load) oil temperature, reduces the time
interval until the next oil change.
C_FAC_CHRG is an additional factor that describes the impact from the turbo charged engines.
During the drive, below a certain oil threshold, the waste equivalent will be loaded with a correction factor
C_FAC_LEVEL_ESTIM_WIV_COR.
The actual fuel consumption will be added up over a period of 2.4s.
The soot equivalent will be set to 0 for the Otto motor.

27.13.2.4.4.4.1 Incrementing of CAN-output and Over?ow-Detection
If temporary summation variable exceeds resolution of CAN-output variable, the CAN-output variable is in-
creased by 1 increment and temporary summation variable is decreased accordingly.
If over?ow of CAN-output variable is recognized,
- the over?ow-bit is set
- the CAN-output variable is reset to 0
- update of CAN-output variable is stopped

� General Information
The WIV- functionality needs the information about the fuel consumption related to the last 100 ms. This
value is calculated depending on the accumulated fuel consumption (FCO_SUM_CAN). If a over?ow of the
FCO_SUM_CAN is reconized, the calculation is shifted to avoid wrong results.
� Application Conditions

then
LV_ACT = ( LV_IGK == 1 ) and ( STATE_VAR_SRV_INTL == 1 )
else
LV_ACT = ( LV_IGK == 1 )
endif

Figure 27.19.6:
27.19.2.1.1.1 Electrical diagnosis of thermal oil level sensor
The time T_EDGE_FALL_LOIL gives the time since the last falling edge was detected by the basic software.
If no falling edge was detected for the calibratable threshold C_T_EDGE_FALL_LOIL_MAX_DIAG_EL, the failure
symptom will be set. This electrical diagnosis can always be suppressed by setting LC_OIL_SENS_EL_DIAG_ENA
= 0 and at the case, that the oil sensor signals are provided via CAN, then the parameter LC_LOIL_SENS_SYS_
CONF is set to zero, which leads into a suppression of this diagnosis which results then always with no failure
symptom detected.

ENLU, Oil plausibility diagnosis
27.19.2.2.1.1.2 Plausibility check for signals of thermal oil level sensor
There are three points to check the plausibility of the thermal oil level sensor. The ?rst point is that the cool off
time has to be between a maximum C_T_COOL_LOIL_MAX_PLAUS and a minimum threshold C_T_COOL_LOIL_
MIN_PLAUS. The second point is that the oil temperature signal has to be between a maximum C_T_TEMP_
SIG_LOIL_MAX_PLAUS and a minimum threshold C_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL_MIN_PLAUS. The third point is that the
ratio of temperature and reference time has to be greater than 1.1.

27.19.2.4 Condition for oil pressure diagnosis for gating of pistons
The actuator for gating of pistons is activated with LV_IGK, therefore the diagnosis is activated with the same
signal and a calibratable delay.
The oil pressure switch is read out with the ACTION_INFR_GetPoilSwiPist and the result is supplied to the
diagnosis.
With LC_OIL_2_PIST_IVS the polarity of the signal LV_OIL_2_PIST is adapted to the piston gating control.

27.19.2.5.1 Warning for no pressure at active piston gating
The warning for no pressure is set if the piston control is off ( piston cooling is active ) and no pressure is
present for a calibratable time.
The warning is reset if Ignition key is switched off.
The diagnosis is if engine is running.
Failure: piston cooling is on and no oil pressure
No-Failure: piston cooling is on and oil pressure
In case of diag-cond active, but error is present, the NO_CDN-block is triggered;
in case of diag-cond active, but no error is present, the CDN_NOSYM-block is triggered.

� General Information
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at reset
LV_INH_DIAG_POIL_H_WARN =0
LV_INH_DIAG_POIL_L_WARN = 0
LV_INH_DIAG_POIL_SWI_H_PLAUS = 0
LV_INH_DIAG_POIL_SWI_L_PLAUS = 0
Activation: at every engine state
Deactivation: -
Recurrence: 100 ms

IF

ELSE
LV_INH_DIAG_POIL_H_WARN =0
LV_INH_DIAG_POIL_L_WARN = 0
LV_INH_DIAG_POIL_SWI_H_PLAUS = 0

NC_IDX_ERR_POIL_SWI_L_
PLAUS
UNUSED UNUSED CC
� General Information
The module A0KE describes the plausibility diagnosis of the low and high oil pressure switch signals. The
output variables are the typical ones of the diagnostic strategy. The error symptoms, the error ?ags itself (LV_
POIL_SWI_L_PLAUS and LV_POIL_SWI_H_PLAUS), the diagnostic conditions, which initiate if the conditions for
checking the plausibility of the oil pressure signals are enabled or disabled, and the end of diagnosis ?ags,
which show normally the end of the time period at which the diagnostic result is valid (time period in which
a failure has to be detected if a failure has occurred or in which the result guarantees, that no failure is in the
system).
In this module also the error ?ag for a warning for error in high or low oil pressure stage also is generated.
The general error treatment is described in the chapters ABC algorithm and Dynamic Error Management :
environmental data, DTC, error classes (priority assignment, lamp management), communication interface,
etc...

Figure 27.21.6:
27.21.1.2.2 Symptom evaluation
The two subsystems CHK_SYM_POIL_SWI_H_PLAUS and CHK_SYM_POIL_SWI_L_PLAUS calculate the different
conditions for setting and clearing the error ?ags of the low and high oil pressure switch plausibility diagno-
sis.
Because of the fact, that no standard ABC counter is used for the detection of a plausibility fault, a strategy
with delay parts and a few more conditions like waiting ?ve seconds after engine is
running or engine stop conditions is used for debouncing the existing failure. Therefore, the generic ?lter type
"no ?lter" is used and the error ?ag is directly set with the (already debounced) upcoming error symptom.
The end of diagnosis ?ags are directly set with an active error symptom or with an additional delay (sum
of debounce time for warning and diagnosis and a calibratable additional delay) based on a valid diagnostic
condition.
The two subsystems CHK_SYM_H_WARN and CHK_SYM_L_WARN calculate the error ?ags for active warning
for error of high or low oil pressure stage. The error are debounced immediately after a Warning ?ag is set

It ensures that critical oil level and temperature reference data are maintained persistently and that the sensor's readings are continuously monitored and validated.

## Function
This Simulink diagram, titled "ENLU. Acquisition of oil sensor" and further described as "Evaluation of the signal of the thermal oil level sensor", is an automotive control logic subsystem. Its primary function is to process and evaluate sensor data related to engine oil level, specifically focusing on thermal aspects and low oil level conditions. It generates several derived signals:
1.  **Reference Oil Level Signals:** Temporary and final values representing a validated high oil level reference.
2.  **Low Oil Level Toggle Signal:** A persistent flag indicating a detected low oil level condition, potentially for warning or engine protection.
3.  **Oil Temperature-Related Signals:** Temporary and final values derived from oil level signals, considering temperature thresholds, possibly for validating sensor health or operating conditions.
4.  **Oil Temperature Status:** A fixed status signal indicating the operational state of the thermal oil level sensor's temperature aspect.

The system incorporates configurable thresholds, clamping logic, and external enabling conditions (`[lv_lt_eq]`, `[lv_min_max]`) to ensure robust signal processing and condition detection.

## Inputs
*   **Sensor/State Inputs:**
    *   `T_SIG_H_LOIL_OLD`: Previous value of the high oil level signal.
    *   `T_SIG_L_LOIL_OLD`: Previous value of the low oil level signal.
    *   `T_SIG_L_LOIL`: Current value of the low oil level signal.
*   **Configuration/Calibration Parameters:**
    *   `C_T_SIG_H_REF_LOIL_MAX`: Configurable maximum reference for the high oil level.
    *   `C_T_SIG_H_REF_LOIL_MIN`: Configurable minimum reference for the high oil level.
    *   `C_T_SIG_H_LOIL_TEMP_MAX`: Configurable maximum temperature threshold related to the high oil level.
    *   `C_T_SIG_H_LOIL_TEMP_MIN`: Configurable minimum temperature threshold related to the high oil level.
    *   `C_T_SIG_LOIL_RATIO_MAX`: Configurable ratio or offset for low oil level calculations.
    *   `C_T_SIG_L_LOIL_MIN`: Configurable minimum threshold for the current low oil level.
*   **Auxiliary Control/Status Flags (external to this diagram):**
    *   `[lv_lt_eq]`: A boolean flag, likely indicating a "less than or equal" condition met or an enable signal from a higher-level logic.
    *   `[lv_min_max]`: A boolean flag, likely indicating a "min/max range" condition met or an enable signal.
    *   `0`: A constant value (interpreted as `false` in logical operations or numeric zero), explicitly provided as an input.

## Outputs
*   `LV_T_SIG_LOIL_REF_TMP` (Bubble 5): Temporary oil level reference signal.
*   `LV_T_SIG_LOIL_REF` (Bubble 1): Final, validated oil level reference signal.

*   `0`: A constant value (interpreted as `false` in logical operations or numeric zero), explicitly provided as an input.

## Outputs

*   `LV_T_SIG_LOIL_REF` (Bubble 1): Final, validated oil level reference signal.
*   `LV_LOIL_TOG_SIG` (Bubble 3): A persistent (toggle) signal indicating a detected low oil level condition.

## Logic Flow

The diagram's logic operates in several parallel paths:

1.  **High Oil Level Reference Signal Derivation (`LV_T_SIG_LOIL_REF_TMP`, `LV_T_SIG_LOIL_REF`):**
    *   The `T_SIG_H_LOIL_OLD` signal is first passed through a series of MIN/MAX blocks. This clamps the signal within a defined range, ensuring it's not less than `C_T_SIG_H_REF_LOIL_MIN` and not greater than `C_T_SIG_H_REF_LOIL_MAX`.
    *   The resulting range-clamped value is then logically ANDed with the `[lv_lt_eq]` flag. If `[lv_lt_eq]` is true, this intermediate result becomes `LV_T_SIG_LOIL_REF_TMP`.
    *   `LV_T_SIG_LOIL_REF_TMP` is further ANDed with the `[lv_min_max]` flag to produce the final `LV_T_SIG_LOIL_REF`. This indicates that the final reference signal is valid only when both `[lv_lt_eq]` and `[lv_min_max]` conditions are true.

2.  **Low Oil Level Toggle Signal Control (`LV_LOIL_TOG_SIG`):**
    *   This output is controlled by a D-FlipFlop (FF) block.
    *   **SET Input Logic:** The FF's `SET` input is activated when three primary conditions are met and logically ANDed together:
        1.  A complex calculation involving `T_SIG_L_LOIL_OLD` and `C_T_SIG_LOIL_RATIO_MAX`: `( |T_SIG_L_LOIL_OLD + C_T_SIG_LOIL_RATIO_MAX| <= T_SIG_L_LOIL_OLD )` is true, AND the `[lv_lt_eq]` flag is true.
        2.  The current low oil level `T_SIG_L_LOIL` is greater than the configurable minimum `C_T_SIG_L_LOIL_MIN`.
        3.  The `[lv_min_max]` flag is true.
    *   **RESET Input Logic:** The `RESET` input of the FF is permanently connected to `LV_T_TEMP_SIG_ST_LOIL`, which is hardcoded to `0` (false) within this diagram. This effectively disables the reset functionality of the FF from within this subsystem. Once `LV_LOIL_TOG_SIG` is set to `1` (true) by the `SET` condition, it will remain `1` and cannot be reset to `0` by this logic. This implies `LV_LOIL_TOG_SIG` acts as a "sticky" warning or event flag.

3.  **Oil Temperature Signal Derivation (`LV_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL_TMP`, `LV_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL`):**
    *   The `T_SIG_H_LOIL_OLD` signal is again clamped, similar to the reference signal path, but using temperature-specific thresholds: `C_T_SIG_H_LOIL_TEMP_MIN` (lower bound) and `C_T_SIG_H_LOIL_TEMP_MAX` (upper bound). The use of the "old high oil level signal" for temperature-related derivations suggests a correlation or specific interpretation of this sensor's output for thermal evaluation.
    *   This range-clamped signal is then logically ANDed with the `[lv_min_max]` flag to produce `LV_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL_TMP`. This temporary signal is active only when `[lv_min_max]` is true.
    *   `LV_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL_TMP` is further ANDed with the `[lv_lt_eq]` flag to generate the final `LV_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL`. This final signal is valid when both `[lv_min_max]` and `[lv_lt_eq]` conditions are met.

4.  **Oil Temperature Status Output (`LV_T_TEMP_SIG_ST_LOIL`):**
    *   This output is directly assigned the constant value `0`.

*   `LV_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL_TMP` is further ANDed with the `[lv_lt_eq]` flag to generate the final `LV_T_TEMP_SIG_LOIL`. This final signal is valid when both `[lv_min_max]` and `[lv_lt_eq]` conditions are met.

4.  **Oil Temperature Status Output (`LV_T_TEMP_SIG_ST_LOIL`):**
    *   This output is directly assigned the constant value `0`. This implies that, within this specific subsystem, the status of the thermal oil level sensor's temperature aspect is always considered `0` (false), possibly indicating "not available," "not validated," or "not OK" from this processing stage. This signal also serves as the disabled `RESET` for the low oil level FF.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and maintain a robust **Dynamic Minimum Oil Level (`LOIL_DYN_MIN`)**. This `LOIL_DYN_MIN` likely serves as a lower bound or a reference value for oil level management within an automotive system. The system incorporates logic to:

2.  **Conditionally update** the dynamic minimum based on processed temporary values and the current oil level.
3.  **Enable/disable** the entire update logic based on a configuration bit.

The accompanying German text states: "The capping is deactivated if either the current oil level is lower (smaller) than the last saved one, or if the dynamic oil level is not available." This directly correlates to the logic flow for `Deactivation_Condition_Prev`.

## Function

This Simulink diagram, titled "BESTIMMUNG_FAC_QLY_SRV_INTL" (Determination of Quality Factor Service Interval), calculates an overall "Quality Factor for Service Interval" (`FAC_QLY_SRV_INTL`). This factor is derived by assessing two main categories: "Travel" (TRV) related conditions and "Light" (LGT) related conditions. For each category, specific configuration bits are checked, input signals are filtered and processed, and a quality factor is determined using a 2D lookup table. The final overall quality factor is the minimum of the calculated "Travel" and "Light" quality factors, implying that the 'worst-case' quality dictates the service interval. This is typical for automotive systems determining maintenance indicators or service life.

## Inputs

1.  **`C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF`**: A configuration word/signal (from a CWWIV block) for oil function service interval, whose individual bits are used to enable or validate different parts of the calculation.
2.  **`LV_AC_TRV_VLD`**: A Boolean or numerical signal indicating the validity status of the "Travel" (TRV) related AC (Air Conditioning or another "AC" system context).
3.  **`AC_TRV_INTL_FIL`**: A filtered signal related to the travel interval, possibly distance or time.
4.  **`AC_TRV_TCS2`**: An input from a "Travel Control System 2" (TCS2) or similar travel-related sensor/logic.
5.  **`xN_SRV_INTL`**: A normalized service interval value (e.g., normalized time or distance) used as an x-axis input for the lookup tables.
6.  **`LV_AC_LGT_VLD`**: A Boolean or numerical signal indicating the validity status of the "Light" (LGT) related AC system. This appears as an input at two different points in the diagram.
7.  **`AC_LGT_INTL_FIL`**: A filtered signal related to the light interval (e.g., operating hours of lights or number of light cycles).
8.  **`AC_LGT_TCS8_CAN`**: An input from a "Light Control System 8" (TCS8), potentially transmitted over a CAN bus.

## Outputs

1.  **`LV_AC_TRV_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL`**: A Boolean signal indicating if travel-related corrections for the service interval are enabled and valid.
2.  **`AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`**: The processed service interval value specific to travel conditions.
3.  **`FAC_QLY_AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`**: The calculated quality factor for the AC Travel Service Interval.
4.  **`LV_AC_LGT_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL`**: A Boolean signal indicating if light-related corrections for the service interval are enabled and valid.
5.  **`LV_AC_LGT_VLD`**: A configuration-validated status of the `LV_AC_LGT_VLD` input signal (derived from an AND operation with `C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF` bit 0).
6.

4.  **`LV_AC_LGT_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL`**: A Boolean signal indicating if light-related corrections for the service interval are enabled and valid.
5.  **`LV_AC_LGT_VLD`**: A configuration-validated status of the `LV_AC_LGT_VLD` input signal (derived from an AND operation with `C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF` bit 0).
6.  **`AC_LGT_SRV_INTL`**: The processed service interval value specific to light conditions.

8.  **`FAC_QLY_SRV_INTL`**: The final overall quality factor for the service interval.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow calculates the overall service interval quality factor by independently evaluating "Travel" and "Light" related aspects, then combining their respective quality factors.

### Part A: Travel (TRV) Quality Factor Calculation

1.  **Travel Correction Enablement (`LV_AC_TRV_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL`, Output 1):**
    *   Bit 1 (`bit_sel=1`) is extracted from the `C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF` configuration input.
    *   This bit is logically ANDed with the `LV_AC_TRV_VLD` input.
    *   The result, `LV_AC_TRV_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL`, is outputted and also used as a control signal later.

2.  **Processed Travel Service Interval (`AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`, Output 2):**
    *   The `C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF` and `AC_TRV_INTL_FIL` signals are processed by an `AC_TRV_INTL_FIL` block.
    *   Its output, along with `AC_TRV_TCS2`, is fed into a further processing block (`_K2ZZ2.1.2_`). This block likely performs specific filtering, scaling, or calculations to determine a raw travel service interval value.
    *   The output of this block, `AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`, is passed through a switch. This switch is controlled by a `Check ~= 0` condition applied to `AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`.
    *   If `AC_TRV_SRV_INTL` is not zero, its value is passed through. Otherwise, a constant value of `1` is outputted, likely serving as a default or nominal value. This final value is outputted as `AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`.

3.  **Travel Quality Factor (`FAC_QLY_AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`, Output 3):**
    *   The `xN_SRV_INTL` input (as `x_val`) and the `AC_TRV_SRV_INTL` (from the previous step, as `y_val`) are fed into a 2D lookup table (`IP_FAC_QLY_AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`). This table determines a preliminary quality factor (`p_val`) based on these two parameters.
    *   The `p_val` is then passed through a second switch, controlled by the `LV_AC_TRV_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL` signal (from step 1).
    *   If `LV_AC_TRV_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL` is true (non-zero), the `p_val` from the lookup table is outputted. Otherwise, a constant `1` (representing nominal or full quality) is outputted.
    *   The final result is `FAC_QLY_AC_TRV_SRV_INTL`.

### Part B: Light (LGT) Quality Factor Calculation

4.  **Light Correction Enablement (`LV_AC_LGT_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL`, Output 4):**
    *   Bit 14 (`bit_sel=14`) is extracted from the `C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF` configuration input.
    *   This bit is logically ANDed with the `LV_AC_LGT_VLD` input.
    *   The result, `LV_AC_LGT_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL`, is outputted and used as a control signal later.

5.  **Validated Light Signal (`LV_AC_LGT_VLD`, Output 5):**
    *   Bit 0 (`bit_sel=0`) is extracted from the `C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF` configuration input.
    *   This bit is logically ANDed with the `LV_AC_LGT_VLD` input.
    *   The result, also labeled `LV_AC_LGT_VLD`, is outputted.

5.  **Validated Light Signal (`LV_AC_LGT_VLD`, Output 5):**
    *   Bit 0 (`bit_sel=0`) is extracted from the `C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF` configuration input.
    *   This bit is logically ANDed with the `LV_AC_LGT_VLD` input.
    *   The result, also labeled `LV_AC_LGT_VLD`, is outputted. This likely represents a configuration-confirmed validity status of the original `LV_AC_LGT_VLD` input.

6.  **Processed Light Service Interval (`AC_LGT_SRV_INTL`, Output 6):**
    *   The `C_LOIL_FCT_SRV_INTL_CONF` and `AC_LGT_INTL_FIL` signals are processed by an `AC_LGT_INTL_FIL` block.
    *   Its output, along with `AC_LGT_TCS8_CAN`, is fed into a further processing block (`_K2ZZ2.1.1_`). Similar to the travel path, this block calculates a raw light service interval value.
    *   The output of this block, `AC_LGT_SRV_INTL`, is passed through a switch. This switch is controlled by a `Check ~= 0` condition applied to `AC_LGT_SRV_INTL`.
    *   If `AC_LGT_SRV_INTL` is not zero, its value is passed through. Otherwise, a constant value of `1` is outputted. This final value is outputted as `AC_LGT_SRV_INTL`.

7.  **Light Quality Factor (`FAC_QLY_AC_LGT_SRV_INTL`, Output 7):**
    *   The `xN_SRV_INTL` input (as `x_val`) and the `AC_LGT_SRV_INTL` (from the previous step, as `y_val`) are fed into another 2D lookup table (`IP_FAC_QLY_AC_LGT_SRV_INTL`). This table calculates a preliminary quality factor (`p_val`).
    *   The `p_val` is then passed through a second switch, controlled by the `LV_AC_LGT_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL` signal (from step 4).
    *   If `LV_AC_LGT_COR_ENA_SRV_INTL` is true (non-zero), the `p_val` from the lookup table is outputted. Otherwise, a constant `1` is outputted.
    *   The final result is `FAC_QLY_AC_LGT_SRV_INTL`.

### Part C: Overall Service Interval Quality Factor

8.  **Overall Quality Factor (`FAC_QLY_SRV_INTL`, Output 8):**
    *   The final overall `FAC_QLY_SRV_INTL` is determined by taking the minimum value of the two category-specific quality factors: `FAC_QLY_AC_TRV_SRV_INTL` (from step 3) and `FAC_QLY_AC_LGT_SRV_INTL` (from step 7). This implies a "lowest common denominator" approach for the overall quality assessment.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate two distinct corrected oil temperature values for the Chinese market, specifically `LOIL_COR_L_CHINA` (Low/Lower Oil Correction for China) and `LOIL_COR_H_CHINA` (High/Higher Oil Correction for China). It applies linear correction models based on international service values for engine speed and oil temperature, utilizing region-specific calibration factors and offsets. This represents a regional adaptation or compensation strategy for an oil temperature model.

## Inputs

The diagram takes the following inputs:

*   **`N_SRV_INTL`**: International service value for engine speed (used in the "Low" correction path).
*   **`TOIL_SRV_INTL`**: International service value for oil temperature (used in the "Low" correction path).
*   **`C_LOIL_FAC_L_N_CHINA`**: A constant factor applied to the engine speed component for the "Low" oil correction in China.
*   **`C_LOIL_FAC_L_CHINA`**: A constant factor applied to the oil temperature component for the "Low" oil correction in China.
*   **`C_LOIL_OFFSET_L_CHINA`**: A constant offset added to the "Low" oil correction for China.
*   **`N_SRV_INTL1`**: International service value for engine speed (used in the "High" correction path).
*   **`TOIL_SRV_INTL1`**: International service value for oil temperature (used in the "High" correction path).
*   **`C_LOIL_FAC_H_N_CHINA`**: A constant factor applied to the engine speed component for the "High" oil correction in China.
*   **`C_LOIL_FAC_H_CHINA`**: A constant factor applied to the oil temperature component for the "High" oil correction in China.
*   **`C_LOIL_OFFSET_H_CHINA`**: A constant offset added to the "High" oil correction for China.
*   **Constants `10000` and `100`**: These are numerical constants used as divisors for scaling within the calculation paths.

## Outputs

The diagram produces two primary outputs:

*   **`LOIL_COR_L_CHINA`**: The corrected oil temperature value for the "Low" or "Lower" range, specific to China.
*   **`LOIL_COR_H_CHINA`**: The corrected oil temperature value for the "High" or "Higher" range, specific to China.

## Logic Flow

The diagram features two structurally identical calculation paths that run in parallel, one for the "Low" (`_L_CHINA`) oil temperature correction and one for the "High" (`_H_CHINA`) oil temperature correction. The logic for each path is detailed below:

**1. Logic Flow for `LOIL_COR_L_CHINA` (Upper Path):**

This path calculates the `LOIL_COR_L_CHINA` output based on `N_SRV_INTL`, `TOIL_SRV_INTL`, and their respective calibration constants.

*   **Engine Speed Contribution (Path 1.1):**
    1.  The input signal `N_SRV_INTL` (International Service Engine Speed) is multiplied by the constant `C_LOIL_FAC_L_N_CHINA` (Low Oil Factor for N in China).
    2.  The result of this multiplication is then divided by the constant value `10000`. This scaled value represents the contribution of engine speed to the low oil temperature correction.

*   **Oil Temperature Contribution (Path 1.2):**
    1.  The input signal `TOIL_SRV_INTL` (International Service Oil Temperature) is multiplied by the constant `C_LOIL_FAC_L_CHINA` (Low Oil Factor for China).
    2.  The result of this multiplication is then divided by the constant value `100`. This scaled value represents the contribution of the oil temperature to the low oil temperature correction.

*   **Final Summation for `LOIL_COR_L_CHINA` (Path 1.3):**
    1.  The output from the Engine Speed Contribution (Path 1.1) and the output from the Oil Temperature Contribution (Path 1.2) are added together.
    2.  To this intermediate sum, the constant `C_LOIL_OFFSET_L_CHINA` (Low Oil Offset for China) is added.
    3.  The final result of this addition is the `LOIL_COR_L_CHINA` output.

**2. Logic Flow for `LOIL_COR_H_CHINA` (Lower Path):**

This path calculates the `LOIL_COR_H_CHINA` output, mirroring the structure of the upper path but using corresponding "High" inputs and constants.

3.  The final result of this addition is the `LOIL_COR_L_CHINA` output.

**2. Logic Flow for `LOIL_COR_H_CHINA` (Lower Path):**

This path calculates the `LOIL_COR_H_CHINA` output, mirroring the structure of the upper path but using corresponding "High" inputs and constants.

*   **Engine Speed Contribution (Path 2.1):**
    1.  The input signal `N_SRV_INTL1` is multiplied by the constant `C_LOIL_FAC_H_N_CHINA`.
    2.  The result is then divided by the constant value `10000`.

*   **Oil Temperature Contribution (Path 2.2):**
    1.  The input signal `TOIL_SRV_INTL1` is multiplied by the constant `C_LOIL_FAC_H_CHINA`.
    2.  The result is then divided by the constant value `100`.

*   **Final Summation for `LOIL_COR_H_CHINA` (Path 2.3):**
    1.  The output from the Engine Speed Contribution (Path 2.1) and the output from the Oil Temperature Contribution (Path 2.2) are added together.
    2.  To this intermediate sum, the constant `C_LOIL_OFFSET_H_CHINA` is added.
    3.  The final result of this addition is the `LOIL_COR_H_CHINA` output.

In essence, both outputs are calculated using a linear equation of the form:
`Output = (N_SRV * N_Factor / 10000) + (TOIL_SRV * TOIL_Factor / 100) + Offset`. The `_L_CHINA` and `_H_CHINA` paths represent different parameterizations of this model.

The title "27.5.2.5.1.1 Min- und Max-Wert Berechnung" (Min- and Max-Value Calculation) and the section "ENLU. Oil temperature model" confirm this.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and track the accumulated distance for a service interval and, based on this interval, determine and store the minimum and maximum dynamic oil level values. These minimum and maximum oil levels are reset when a new service interval, defined by accumulated distance, is initiated.

## Inputs

1.  **ACTION_FARM_GetPermission**: A boolean signal indicating permission to perform certain actions or calculations.
2.  **PRM_FID**: A parameter identification or value, used in conjunction with permissions.
3.  **NO_FID_ENLU_SUM_DIST_ENA**: A boolean enable signal for the summation of distance, likely related to an oil level monitoring function.
4.  **CTR_KM_CAN**: A counter representing total kilometers, received via a CAN bus.
5.  **DIST_CTR_SRV_INTL_in**: The current or initial value for the service interval distance counter. This value serves as the reference for determining when the service interval resets.
6.  **<LV_LOIL_DYN_VLD>**: "Level Low Oil Dynamic Valid" - a boolean signal indicating the validity of the dynamic low oil level measurement.
7.  **<LOIL_DYN>**: "Low Oil Dynamic" - the actual measured dynamic oil level value.
8.  **LOIL_MAX_SRV_INTL_in**: The initial or current maximum oil level value stored for the service interval.
9.  **LOIL_MIN_SRV_INTL_in**: The initial or current minimum oil level value stored for the service interval.

## Outputs

1.  **DIST_CTR_SRV_INTL_out**: The calculated output for the service interval distance counter. This output also serves as a reset trigger for the min/max oil level tracking.
2.  **LOIL_MAX_SRV_INTL_out**: The tracked maximum dynamic oil level value within the current service interval.
3.  **LOIL_MIN_SRV_INTL_out**: The tracked minimum dynamic oil level value within the current service interval.

## Logic Flow

The diagram can be logically divided into two main sections: Service Interval Distance Accumulation and Min/Max Oil Level Tracking.

### 1. Service Interval Distance Accumulation and Reset Logic

*   **Permission and Validity Check**: `ACTION_FARM_GetPermission` and `PRM_FID` are processed by a `PRM_LV_PRMS` block. Its output, combined with a constant `65535` and an `AND` gate, likely forms an overall enable or permission signal for the distance accumulation.
*   **Kilometer Difference Calculation**:
    *   The `CTR_KM_CAN` input is compared with its previous value (stored in a `1/z` block, which is an accumulator or delay).
    *   The difference (`CTR_KM_CAN - previous_CTR_KM_CAN`) is calculated.
    *   Multiple conditions are checked: `CTR_KM_CAN` > 0, `(CTR_KM_CAN - previous_CTR_KM_CAN)` > 0, and `NO_FID_ENLU_SUM_DIST_ENA` is true. These conditions, along with the permission signal, enable the accumulation of distance.

*   The difference (`CTR_KM_CAN - previous_CTR_KM_CAN`) is calculated.
    *   Multiple conditions are checked: `CTR_KM_CAN` > 0, `(CTR_KM_CAN - previous_CTR_KM_CAN)` > 0, and `NO_FID_ENLU_SUM_DIST_ENA` is true. These conditions, along with the permission signal, enable the accumulation of distance.
    *   *Self-Correction/Accumulator Reset Logic for `CTR_KM_CAN`*: The description "To enable the accumulator, the difference between new and old value of CTR_KM_CAN and also the old value itself have to be greater than zero and the CAN message has to be valid" directly pertains to this sub-section. The `1/z` block with `init = 0` acts as an accumulator for the `CTR_KM_CAN` value, ensuring that only positive increments are considered and the accumulator is enabled correctly.
*   **Distance Accumulation**: The calculated valid kilometer difference is fed into a `Σ` (Summation/Accumulator) block. This block accumulates the distance, taking `DIST_CTR_SRV_INTL_in` as an initial or reference value (`x_in`) and potentially resetting based on `x_out` and an enable input (`E`) derived from the preceding AND gate logic. The output `y` represents the accumulated distance, here labeled `C_DIST_SRV_INTL`.
*   **Service Interval Reset Determination**:
    *   The accumulated distance `C_DIST_SRV_INTL` is compared with `DIST_CTR_SRV_INTL_in` using a `>=` (greater than or equal to) comparator.
    *   If `C_DIST_SRV_INTL` is greater than or equal to `DIST_CTR_SRV_INTL_in`, a `1` (true) signal is generated; otherwise, `0` (false).
    *   This `1`/`0` signal acts as a reset trigger (`init`) for the `DIST_CTR_SRV_INTL_out` block (another `1/z` accumulator/memory). This output (`DIST_CTR_SRV_INTL_out`) thus represents the current service interval status, with a "1" indicating a reset condition (new service interval).
    *   The generated reset signal is then routed to the `R` (Reset) inputs of the `S&H` (Sample & Hold) blocks in the min/max oil level tracking section, linking the service interval calculation to the oil level tracking.

### 2. Minimum/Maximum Oil Level Tracking

There are two identical sub-sections, one for maximum and one for minimum oil level.

*   **Input Conditions**: Both sections rely on the `<LV_LOIL_DYN_VLD>` signal to ensure that the dynamic oil level reading (`<LOIL_DYN>`) is valid.
*   **Maximum Oil Level Tracking**:
    *   The `<LOIL_DYN>` is compared with the currently stored maximum value (`LOIL_MAX_SRV_INTL_in`) using a `>` (greater than) comparator.
    *   An `AND` gate combines the `<LV_LOIL_DYN_VLD>` signal with the result of this comparison.
    *   If both conditions are true (oil level is valid AND current dynamic oil level is greater than the stored maximum), the `S&H` (Sample & Hold) block is enabled (`E` input).
    *   The `S&H` block is initialized with `LOIL_MAX_SRV_INTL_in` (`IV` input and `x_in`). When enabled, it samples `<LOIL_DYN>` (`u` input) and updates its output (`y`, `x_out`) to this new maximum value.
    *   The `R` (Reset) input of this `S&H` block is connected to the service interval reset signal from the top section. When a new service interval starts, the `S&H` block resets, effectively starting the max-tracking for the new interval from `LOIL_MAX_SRV_INTL_in`.
    *   The output `y` from this `S&H` block is `LOIL_MAX_SRV_INTL_out`.
*   **Minimum Oil Level Tracking**:
    *   This section operates identically to the maximum tracking, but uses a `<` (less than) comparator to find the minimum value.
    *   `<LOIL_DYN>` is compared with `LOIL_MIN_SRV_INTL_in`.
    *   An `AND` gate combines `<LV_LOIL_DYN_VLD>` with the comparison result.
    *   The `S&H` block is initialized with `LOIL_MIN_SRV_INTL_in`.

*   `<LOIL_DYN>` is compared with `LOIL_MIN_SRV_INTL_in`.
    *   An `AND` gate combines `<LV_LOIL_DYN_VLD>` with the comparison result.
    *   The `S&H` block is initialized with `LOIL_MIN_SRV_INTL_in`. When enabled (valid AND `LOIL_DYN` < current min), it samples `<LOIL_DYN>` and updates its output.
    *   It is also reset by the same service interval reset signal.
    *   The output `y` from this `S&H` block is `LOIL_MIN_SRV_INTL_out`.

In essence, the diagram ensures that the minimum and maximum oil levels are tracked accurately within each service interval, with the interval boundaries defined by a kilometer-based counter and its associated reset logic.

## Function

The primary function of this diagram, titled "Disable correction calculation" within the "ENLU, Oil dilution" context, is to determine when a specific oil dilution-related correction should be disabled, calculate an integrated fuel mass value related to oil change, and derive an oil change correction factor. It essentially acts as a logical decision-making unit for managing oil dilution compensation strategies based on various fuel-in-oil parameters and thresholds.

## Inputs

*   **`MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL`**: Integrated fuel mass in oil, a continuous value.
*   **`C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_MIN_OIL_CHG`**: Calibration constant: Minimum integrated fuel mass in oil threshold to trigger an oil change.
*   **`LV_OIL_CHG_ACT_TRG`**: Logical value (boolean): Indicates if an oil change is actively triggered.
*   **`MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_OIL_CHG`**: Integrated fuel mass in oil at the time of an oil change event or previous calculation.
*   **`MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO`**: Ratio of integrated fuel mass in oil, potentially normalized.
*   **`C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_DI`**: Calibration constant: Threshold for the integrated fuel ratio related to disabling a direct injection (DI) correction.
*   **`C_OIL_CHG_COR_H`**: Calibration constant: High (or maximum) oil change correction factor.
*   **`C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_THR`**: Calibration constant: Threshold for the integrated fuel ratio for selecting the oil change correction factor.
*   **`C_OIL_CHG_COR`**: Calibration constant: Nominal oil change correction factor.

*   **`C_OIL_CHG_COR_H`**: Calibration constant: High (or maximum) oil change correction factor.
*   **`C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_THR`**: Calibration constant: Threshold for the integrated fuel ratio for selecting the oil change correction factor.
*   **`C_OIL_CHG_COR`**: Calibration constant: Nominal oil change correction factor.

## Outputs

*   **`LV_OIL_CHG_COR_D`**: Logical value (boolean): Indicates whether the oil change correction should be disabled (true) or enabled (false).
*   **`MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_CHG`**: Calculated integrated fuel mass in oil related to the current oil change status.
*   **`FAC_OIL_CHG_COR`**: Calculated factor for oil change correction.

## Logic Flow

The diagram's logic can be broken down into three main parallel calculations for its three outputs:

### 1. `LV_OIL_CHG_COR_D` (Disable Oil Change Correction) Calculation

This output is determined by an `OR` logic block, meaning if *any* of its input conditions are true, the oil change correction is disabled.

*   **Condition A: Low Integrated Fuel in Oil:**
    *   `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL` is compared to `C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_MIN_OIL_CHG`.
    *   If `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL < C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_MIN_OIL_CHG`, this condition is true.

*   **Condition B: Active Oil Change Trigger:**
    *   The input `LV_OIL_CHG_ACT_TRG` directly feeds into the `OR` block. If `LV_OIL_CHG_ACT_TRG` is true, this condition is met.

*   **Condition C: Integrated Fuel Ratio Below Disablement Threshold:**
    *   `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO` passes through a `phys_max` block (clamping it to a physical maximum).
    *   The result is compared to `C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_DI`.
    *   If `(phys_max(MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO)) < C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_DI`, this condition is true.

*   **Condition D: Combined Oil Change Status Logic:**
    *   Two switch-like blocks (labeled `Check == 0`, controlled by `LV_OIL_CHG_ACT_TRG`) are used:
        *   One passes `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_OIL_CHG` if `LV_OIL_CHG_ACT_TRG == 0` (no active trigger), otherwise potentially resets or passes another value.
        *   Another passes `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL` if `LV_OIL_CHG_ACT_TRG == 0`, otherwise resets/passes another value.
    *   These processed values, along with `LV_OIL_CHG_ACT_TRG`, are fed into a sum block `(+)` and then a `V.7.2` block (likely a min/max or saturation).
    *   The output of `V.7.2` is then compared to `C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_DI` using a `<` block. If the former is less than the latter, this condition is true.

*   **Final `LV_OIL_CHG_COR_D` Output:** The `LV_OIL_CHG_COR_D` output is `true` if any of Conditions A, B, C, or D are `true`.

### 2. `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_CHG` Calculation

This output represents an updated or selected integrated fuel mass for an oil change.

*   **Input Processing:** `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_OIL_CHG` is fed into a `V.7.2` block.
*   **Conditional Selection:** A switch block (`V.6.1`) selects between two values based on a control condition:
    *   One input to the switch is the output of the `V.7.2` block.
    *   The other input is the constant `C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_DI`.
    *   The control condition for this switch is `(phys_max(MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO)) < C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_DI` (Condition C from above).
    *   If the condition is `true` (ratio is below disablement threshold), one input is selected; otherwise, the other is selected.
*   The selected value is the final `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_CHG` output.

### 3.

*   The control condition for this switch is `(phys_max(MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO)) < C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_DI` (Condition C from above).
    *   If the condition is `true` (ratio is below disablement threshold), one input is selected; otherwise, the other is selected.
*   The selected value is the final `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_CHG` output.

### 3. `FAC_OIL_CHG_COR` (Oil Change Correction Factor) Calculation

This output provides a correction factor based on the integrated fuel ratio.

*   **Ratio Threshold Check:**
    *   `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO` is compared to `C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_THR` using a `>` (greater than) block.
    *   If `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO > C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_THR`, the output of this comparison is `true`.

*   **Correction Factor Selection:** A switch block (labeled `Check == 0`, controlled by the output of the greater-than comparison) selects between two constant correction factors:
    *   If the comparison `MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO > C_MASS_FUEL_INT_OIL_RATIO_THR` is `false` (meaning the ratio is not above the threshold), it selects `C_OIL_CHG_COR` (nominal correction).
    *   If the comparison is `true` (meaning the ratio is above the threshold), it selects `C_OIL_CHG_COR_H` (high correction).
*   The selected value is the final `FAC_OIL_CHG_COR` output.

## Function

The primary function of this module, titled "ENLU. Oil pressure", is to **monitor and manage the engine oil pressure system**. It processes various sensor inputs related to oil pressure switches, oil temperature, engine speed, and system states to detect abnormal conditions, generate warning signals, and provide diagnostic information. This ensures the engine operates within safe oil pressure parameters and alerts the driver or other control units to potential issues.

*   **TOIL_WIV**: Oil temperature (possibly "Warm-Up In-Vehicle" or "Warning Indication Value").

## Outputs

2.  **Clear a low oil pressure warning flag:** This flag is deactivated when the low oil pressure condition has sufficiently recovered for a defined period, or other clearing conditions (e.g., engine speed) are met.
3.  **Clear a high oil pressure warning flag:** This flag is deactivated based on specific events, notably a transition of the ignition key.

This design ensures that warnings are only displayed when necessary and are cleared appropriately once the underlying issue is resolved or context changes.

## Logic Flow

The system operates in two main sub-systems:

### Sub-system 1: Warning Flag Setting (Figure 27.119)

This sub-system uses an SR Flip-Flop to latch an oil pressure warning based on trigger events and conditions.

2.  **Set Condition Evaluation:** An `AND V.5.4` gate receives the outputs from `V.5.6` and `V.5.3` (top instance). If both conditions are true (e.g., a specific event is detected and a required state is maintained), the output of the `AND` gate becomes active.
3.  **Warning Latching (SR Flip-Flop):**

## Function

This Simulink diagram implements a latching mechanism for two distinct oil pressure warning conditions: one for low oil pressure and another for high oil pressure. Its primary function is to capture and hold a warning state, ensuring that once a specific oil pressure threshold is crossed (either too low or too high), the corresponding warning remains active until it is explicitly cleared. This prevents fleeting sensor readings from causing momentary warnings and ensures that persistent issues are properly indicated.

## Inputs

1.  **<LV_POIL_SWI_L_SET>**: A boolean signal that, when active, triggers (sets) the low oil pressure warning. "LV_POIL_SWI_L" likely refers to "Low Oil Pressure Switch - Low threshold".
2.  **<LV_POIL_SWI_L_CLR>**: A boolean signal that, when active, clears (resets) the low oil pressure warning.
3.  **<LV_POIL_SWI_H_SET>**: A boolean signal that, when active, triggers (sets) the high oil pressure warning. "LV_POIL_SWI_H" likely refers to "Low Oil Pressure Switch - High threshold" (the 'LV' part might be a generic prefix for 'Level Value' or 'Logic Value' rather than 'Low Voltage' in this context).
4.  **<LV_POIL_SWI_H_CLR>**: A boolean signal that, when active, clears (resets) the high oil pressure warning.

## Outputs

1.  **LV_POIL_SWI_L_WARN**: A latched boolean signal indicating an active low oil pressure warning. This output will remain active once set until it is cleared.
2.  **LV_POIL_SWI_H_WARN**: A latched boolean signal indicating an active high oil pressure warning. This output will remain active once set until it is cleared.

## Logic Flow

The diagram consists of two identical, independent Set-Reset (SR) latch circuits, each built around an "FF" block, which represents a flip-flop (a fundamental memory element in digital logic).

**1. Low Oil Pressure Warning Latch (Top Sub-system):**
    *   **Component**: An "FF" (Flip-Flop) block with a SET input, an RST (Reset) input, and a Q output. The 'V.5.4' likely denotes a specific variant, version, or parameter for the flip-flop.
    *   **Set Operation**: When the input signal **<LV_POIL_SWI_L_SET>** becomes active (e.g., transitions from low to high, or is continuously high), it triggers the SET input of the flip-flop.
    *   **Latching**: Upon activation of the SET input, the flip-flop's Q output goes active (e.g., high). This state is latched, meaning the Q output remains active even if the **<LV_POIL_SWI_L_SET>** signal subsequently becomes inactive.
    *   **Reset Operation**: To deactivate the warning, the input signal **<LV_POIL_SWI_L_CLR>** must become active, triggering the RST input of the flip-flop.
    *   **Clearing**: When the RST input is active, the flip-flop's Q output becomes inactive (e.g., low).
    *   **Output**: The Q output of this flip-flop directly generates the **LV_POIL_SWI_L_WARN** signal, which is then passed to a labeled output block.

**2. High Oil Pressure Warning Latch (Bottom Sub-system):**
    *   This sub-system functions identically to the low oil pressure warning latch.
    *   The **<LV_POIL_SWI_H_SET>** input controls the SET operation for the high oil pressure warning.
    *   The **<LV_POIL_SWI_H_CLR>** input controls the RST operation for the high oil pressure warning.
    *   The Q output of this flip-flop generates the **LV_POIL_SWI_H_WARN** signal, which is then passed to a labeled output block.

In summary, each warning condition (low or high oil pressure) is managed by an independent SR latch. A warning is "set" when its corresponding set input is pulsed or held active, and it remains active until a separate "clear" input is pulsed or held active, providing a memory function for these critical fault indicators.

## Function

This Simulink diagram, titled "OIL LEVEL 1", is designed to process the first engine oil level reported via CAN. Its primary function is to:
1.  **Calculate a compensated oil level volume (`OIL_LEVEL1_VOL`)**: It corrects the raw CAN oil level using a lookup table and an offset, then scales it.
2.  **Determine a specific non-plausibility status (`LV_OIL_LEVEL1_NPLAUS`)**: It evaluates multiple conditions including action permissions, CAN communication health, and the raw oil level's validity range.

## Inputs

*   **`<ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3>`**: A trigger or signal indicating whether the system has permission to perform the oil level processing action.
*   **`NC_FID_T_OIL_LEVEL_1_NPLAUS`**: A boolean flag indicating an initial or fundamental non-plausibility status for the first oil level reading.
*   **`NC_T_OIL_LEVEL_CAN_INI`**: A boolean flag indicating the initialization status of the CAN communication specifically for oil level data. A non-plausible state would typically be "not initialized".
*   **`NC_T_OIL_LEVEL_CAN_ERR`**: A boolean flag indicating if there's a CAN communication error related to the oil level data. A non-plausible state would be "error present".
*   **`<T_OIL_LEVEL1_CAN>`**: The raw, uncorrected oil level value received from the vehicle's CAN bus. This is a primary measurement input.
*   **`C_T_OIL_LEVEL_MIN_NPLAUS`**: A constant or parameter defining the minimum plausible threshold for the raw oil level value.
*   **`C_T_OIL_LEVEL_MAX_NPLAUS`**: A constant or parameter defining the maximum plausible threshold for the raw oil level value.
*   **`<OIL_LEVEL_COR_SRV_INTL>`**: A corrected or base oil level value, likely related to service interval compensation or an initial offset.
*   **`C_OIL_SLOP_LEVEL`**: A constant or parameter representing a scaling factor or gain used in the final oil volume calculation.

## Outputs

*   **`LV_OIL_LEVEL1_NPLAUS` (Output Port 3)**: A boolean flag that becomes TRUE only if a specific combination of non-plausible conditions are met (action permitted AND CAN not initialized AND CAN error present AND oil level out of range).
*   **`OIL_LEVEL1_VOL` (Output Port 1)**: The final calculated oil level, compensated and scaled to represent a volume.
*   **`OIL_LEVEL1` (Output Port 2)**: An intermediate calculated oil level value, corrected by a lookup table and an initial service interval offset, before the final volume scaling.

The diagram's logic can be divided into two main, concurrently executed branches:
